This reflection pushed me to delete all my works from streaming and upload only one track. A single 3.5-hour track combining all seven albums into one. It is titled "Freezing away from the streams." 
It’s anti-playlist, anti-single, anti-short-song. It keeps the works together as intended and it asks the listener to search for what they want, or to sit with it. Similar to a tape cassette. I legacied that track so that it will be up "forever" without having to pay again. 
My music is still available on Bandcamp for now. 
In the future, I think my work will live in a more creative space. Releasing music should be fun and have a shape that is truer to the process.

title: 55. CYCLICAL PROCESSING
text:
I am bringing the same mindset I used outdoors with the field recorder into live performance. Whether in stereo, quadraphonic, octophonic, or bigger multi-channel structures, I’ve been working toward a unified approach to performance. One that adapts to any system, but always centers space itself as an instrument. 
Microphones are placed to capture the space. Audience movement, instruments, noise, machinery hum is processed live, reshaped, degraded, and fed back into the room and back into the system. I can interact and steer it into form. 
Instead of deciding what sounds will be used, I focus on building the containers that will shape those sounds. It is a system I can use anywhere, as a solo artist or in collaborations. My instrument is the shaping of space. 
It is responsive and alive.

title: 56. NO COMPROMISE ON EXPERIENCE
text:
I took part in a program called Composer's Lab, run by New Amsterdam Records. We met weekly as a group of seven composers to talk about music and share whatever we were working on.

During these meetings, I shared that since my album Timelines, I had recorded and fully mixed two complete albums that I never released. Not because they didn't sound good, but because I simply didn't feel it.

I realized my work had always been built around creating temporary sound installations in real spaces, then extracting fragments through recording experiments and shaping them into albums afterward. The problem was that the album was never the same as being in the room, and it removed any possibility for interaction, which had become increasingly central to my process.

I also shared that I no longer enjoyed the release process. Reducing ideas to a single track on a streaming platform felt disproportionately small compared to the original intention. I wondered whether it made more sense to build a virtual space instead, something you could walk through to feel the space more directly.

William Brittelle, who facilitated the sessions, suggested that maybe I shouldn't release albums at all. Don't compromise on the experience. Maybe the work should only exist in physical space, in that moment, and that's it. It might be harder to bring people to it in the short term, but in the long term, you would have something people need to go to physically to experience.

That idea shifted everything. Am I a musician if I don't follow the usual path of compose → record → release → tour? At the same time, it explained why I had always gravitated toward video, and why my work had connected more through documentation than through albums themselves.

Accepting that I wouldn't release albums in the near future came with some grief around recording, sound design, and mixing, which are processes I genuinely enjoy. But letting go of the album as the goal allowed me to refocus on what I was already starting to do: recording spaces, processing them live, and feeding them back into the room. Real-time re-amping. Real-time room shaping. Grabbing sound from the audience, myself, and the environment, and improvising with it.

The recording and sound design weren't gone, they were just happening live now.

Scaling this up recreated a problem I had faced before. Carrying microphones, cables, interfaces, a computer, and instruments to every shows is not optimal. I prefer setups that are quick to set up and easy to commute with.

title: 57. DAISY SEED
text:
I started imagining all of this inside a single object. A small, custom device that could do everything, with dedicated personal DSP that would be more intentional than the pedals I was using. It would let me keep the sound shaping I loved, but make it portable and immediate.

For eight months, I worked on developing this device, and every show became a testing site. Organically, I started carving out a little space for myself in NYC and people started asking me to play more. I said yes to everything to force deadlines and public stress-tests. After each performance, I wrote lists of bugs, missing controls, and future ideas. I learned on stage that without a screen, I couldn't tell what was active. I discovered the CPU limits of the Daisy Seed during an outdoor festival, when a burst of harsh digital noise took over my lush ambient sounds. I learned which button combinations made sense or were too complicated, how sensitive the microphone needed to be to work in all spaces, and why a solid barrel connector matters.

Playing different spaces with an instrument that treats space itself as the sound source became the real education. Quiet rooms where there was nothing to capture. Loud rooms where people talked so much that all I ended up doing was pushing their voices back at them, causing them to speak even louder. Loft shows where a party below was so loud that people only realized the bass thumping wasn't part of my sound once I stopped playing.

Each of these moments helped clarify what I'm trying to do.

Magnify space.
Layer iterations.
Bring awareness to existing sound.
Anchor people in their own presence.
Improvise.

To create situations that exist somewhere between performance, self-generative installation, and interactive media.
